messages: 2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:05): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Heh, I always cringe whenever I see 'would of'.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:08): what is it about 'would of' that makes you cringe?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:09): the fact that it's grammatically incorrect version of would've or would have?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:09): The fact that it's so obviously wrong
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:10): Zakim, drop MIke
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:11): it's just one of those phrases that people hear spoken, mis-interpret and treat as an idiomatic phrase. Happens quite a bit with a few phrases.

2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:15): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I never can understand how people manage to get that done. If I say would have/would've it doesn't sound like would of. Maybe it's because I learnt Queen's English in school.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:16): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: That assumes learning English entirely through audio and never even covering basic verb conjugation
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:17): A large part of my English didn't come from audio
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:17): But nor it come from learning formal grammar rules
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:18): Eliminate vocabulary and the ratios change I expect
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:19): I'd say the majority of the grammar I learnt aurally was mainly the more simple rules
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:20): And the increasingly complex came more from writing
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (14:21): 2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d: In standard American, "would've" and "would of" do sound identical.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:21): hmm? "would've" and "would of" sound quite similar in home counties british english (which I assume you mean by "Queeen's English" since I can't imagine you learnt to speak in an incredibly posh accent)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:21): 2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d, that depends on the speaker's accent and how much they stress the 'o' in 'of'
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:23): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: both "wooduv" but some people say "woulda" instead
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:23): http://dev.w3.org/geo/api/spec-source-orientation.html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:24): question:
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (14:24): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Yeah, but I'd pronounce both as "wooda" too.  ^_^
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:24): http://dev.w3.org/geo/api/spec-source-orientation.html#examples
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:25): "A device lying flat on a horizontal surface with the top of the screen pointing West has the following orientation... theta: 90"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:25): why is that theta: -90 ?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:26): why is that not theta: -90 ?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:26): that is, why positive 90 and not negative 90?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:27): "C is perpendicular to the screen, positive out of the screen... rotate the device frame around its C axis by theta degrees, with theta in [0, 360)"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (14:28): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Because it's been rotated 90 degrees in the positive direction (CCW).
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:28): it follows from that it cannot be negative
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:28): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: CCW is positive?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (14:28): Always has been.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:28): dint know that
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (14:29): Standard rules of angles is that CCW is positive, and the 0 angle is to the east.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (14:29): (When directionality is important, as well as simple magnitude of change.)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:29): damn I'm ig'nant
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:30): btw, why do we need CSSRule.type or Node.type?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:30): is that something inflicted upon us by Java?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:30): Node.nodeType even
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:31): I guess it's somewhat useful when iterating through a bunch of them; nevermind
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:32): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: I'd be cautious in calling any geometry conventions a "standard" :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:32): People can't even decide which handedness to use for axes, or which way around to write matrices
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:33): That orientation spec says "Positive rotation around an axis is defined as clockwise when viewed along the positive direction of the axis."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:34): oh, handedness... this is ringing a bell now, thumbs-up, positive is in direction of the way fingers curl
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:34): so something like that

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:36): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: The spec says C is perpendicular to the screen and outwards, so if the screen is lying flat on its back then C is vertically upwards
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:36): so you have to look along the upwards direction
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:36): i.e. from beneath
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:36): and then rotate clockwise (for positive angles)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:36): which is equivalent to anticlockwise when you're looking down on it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:37): I see
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:39): (and you start with the screen lying flat on its back with the top pointing North)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:39): (and rotate around C first)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:39): (so that's the right way to turn it to make its top point West)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:57): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: btw, some chrome devs in Japan are starting work CSS Paged Media implementation
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:00): sad day for paper
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:00): but euh, yeah, the CSSOM story is kind of weak for paged media
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:01): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: is the CSSDOM a comedy or a tragedy?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:01): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: is the editor of the CSSOM spec a tragic hero?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:03): he lacks time and superpowers
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:03): wants to go and study English.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:03): but he's doing some work on it at the moment, mostly fixing minor things
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:04): ...and he will eventually reveal himself in his full glory
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:04): like the Transfiguration
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:05): wonders when that comment comes from a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 whether it means a Gnostic Transfiguration
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:05): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, it's just me
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:07): Is it strange that I find a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 more understandable when he speaks Japanese?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:08): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: "I believe he's coming back, like he said, ... in the twinkling of an eye, he'll split the Eastern sky"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:15): heh, "The Web leaves no edge case unexercised"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:29): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, but anything specific about the CSSOM?
2cc83be0233de2f6f7813e9af67fd5de (15:29): has there been discussion on having something like an validate=false attribute on input elements?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:30): there is a novalidate attribute on submit buttons
2cc83be0233de2f6f7813e9af67fd5de (15:30): oh, I'll try that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:30): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: no, was just thinking that it'd be nice to see CSSOM spec see that light of day eventually
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:31): here it is: http://dev.w3.org/csswg/cssom/
2cc83be0233de2f6f7813e9af67fd5de (15:31): I think it would be useful on an input level though
2cc83be0233de2f6f7813e9af67fd5de (15:32): I have some URL fields which are to contain variables represented with %s
2cc83be0233de2f6f7813e9af67fd5de (15:32): but not all fields in the form
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:33): just use type=text?
2cc83be0233de2f6f7813e9af67fd5de (15:33): yes, I'm doing that now
2cc83be0233de2f6f7813e9af67fd5de (15:33): but it will mean other benefits of the URL fields are lost, such as special keyboards on mobiles and URL completion
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:34): wonders if Leonard is a Larry-proxy :p

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:44): regarding http://www.useragentman.com/blog/2010/03/09/cross-browser-css-transforms-even-in-ie/ what font rasterization method do Chrome and Opera use on Windows?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:45): wildly guesses Firefox and Safari let the Windows font rasterizer perform the rasterization with a matrix
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:46): AFAIK we have our own
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): do Chrome and Opera do the same bug force ClearType on even if the user has it off system-wide?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: ok
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: can you say if it's FreeType or something yet different?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:46): (But that's just a vague memory, and may be totally wrong)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:47): Chrome on Linux in those screenshots is using subpixel AA but Windows and Mac aren't
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:47): which hints at OS font rasterizer

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:49): aside: I don't understand why systems offer subpixel AA. On my LCDs, the color channels are always so well aligned that grayscale AA looks nice but subpixel AA looks like colors are leaking at the edges of black glyphs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:50): always configures Macs to use the "CRT" AA and Ubuntu to use grayscale AA
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:50): even with LCDs that is
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:52): am I using unusually good screens or is subpixel AA snakeoil?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:59): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I get noticably nicer (to my eyes) results with subpixel smoothing
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:59): But I think that it is more related to expectations than anything
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:03): has had varying results
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:03): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, I'm not particularly interested to be honest in putting CSSOM on TR/

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:04): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, I have personally not noticed a whole lot of positive things coming from TR/. Actually mostly emails from people being confused or looking at TR/ while they should be looking at the editor's draft...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:06): prefers it with sub-pixel rendering enabled on Linux
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:06): on a cheap laptop display and on a better LCD
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:07): It's subtle enough that I don't notice the colours, and its makes vertical lines a tiny bit thicker so they better match the non-axis-aligned lines, I think
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:18): On my display subpixel rendering gives better contrast compared to greyscale smoothing

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (16:21): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: maybe you‚Äôve got good eyesight, or maybe you‚Äôre sitting too close to the monitor. AA works when your brain does the smoothing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:25): I also think ClearType is ugly
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:26): and one reason I didn't switch from Mac to Gnome earlier was that around 2003 FreeType sucked too much
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (16:27): typography on Windows is offensive :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:28): hinting is *so* nineties
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:28): shape-preserving AA FTW!

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (16:51): Argh, I really wish Richard would send plain-text emails.  It's very apparent that there's a mismatch between the visual size of some font metric on his screen and mine.  (Likely pts.)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:57): just reads it as text/plain
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:07): Hello
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:08): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I'd read it as text/plain too, except that some people use indent-based quoting which I need to read as HTML to follow.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:09): If people only used semantic markup ;)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:11): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, either my email client picks up on that or I just don't read those emails... not sure which it is
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:11): I want everyone to just use Markdown like normal people.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:17): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: I think you need a new definition of normal
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:17): The point of Markdown is that it *is* what normal people type.  ^_^
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:19): No, it's what some dude thinks looks somewhat similar to what normal people type
